Hi Kino,  
This example chart looks great Kino!   
Good to see you have found time to work on this strategy. You're such a good coder, we owe you so much..... many many thanks!!  
  
I would like to give some remarks.   
  
1) In my opinion R1 is to slow for identifying good scalping trade setups. So my suggestion is to use RTick or Price. I think RTick is the best solution. **John, what is your thought?**  
  
2) The upper and the lower Ribbon on which distance should be calculated can be R5 or R15, just depending on which Ribbons are neighbours. **John, what is your thought?** **R1?**  
  
3) As JE allready brought to attention, it would be nice if you could add a numerical display of the distances, I think on the right side of the indicator window. So you could read it if the chart is shifted by the chart shift button. I have made a note on the chart example.   
  
4) I am asking myself if this indicator can replace the close above ribbons indicator. The best trade setups when price is <> all ribbons is if _RTick did go under or above the other Ribbons_. In these cases your indi which is in preperation would give:   
\- solely blue bars if RTick is above all ribbons (indi value>zero)   
\- solely red bars (indi value< zero, if RTick is below all ribbons)  
\- blue AND simultaneously red bars if RTick is between the Ribbons, only draw these bars if there is enough pipdistance to one of the ribbons. The distance should be calculated to the nearest flanks  
\- no signal bars if RTick is inside any of the other ribbons, and if price is between the ribbons while pipdistance is too small.  
  
5) Using Rtick instead of Price above/under Ribbons .....gives the advantage that the indicator gives cleaner signals and later on .... cleaner/less sound and text alerts.........Too many alerts isn't fine......Otherwise a time delay should be added which adjust that the indicator shouldn't give a new signal within x minutes after the last signal (in the same direction).  
  
6) Using Rtick instead of Price above/under Ribbons .....gives the disadvantage that signals will come later on, so you have less time to make your homework for trade entry.  
  
The chartexample which I attached is just a hand drawn trial. It's not really okay. Kino or John, If you need a better/clearer one, just ask.

Hi LSs,  
sorry for rudely quoting your post ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
I saw your question on your chart. here is my answer.  
The 3 TF ribbons are coming together from different directions and all traders have to decide what they think price will go to do. Some were long and some others were short. So it can take some time before the decision for the next direction is taken, and it could also go to a sideways market for a while.   
On the first point you marked TF1 is going up and price is going down, with a gap between these two.   
At your second mark, TF1 is much better situated. Better in relation to price and better in relation to higher TF ribbons. Here it is more likely that price will going to fall.   
  
Overall, in case of a reversal it is better if TF1 is falling out of the bigger TF zones and TickRibbon makes a pullback to TF1 zone.   
  
I noticed this is a chart from februari. You're really doing a huge backtest!

maybe you have to many history bars on the ribbons in your template.   
  
Try to check and if needed: change in MetaEditor the settings of the kino_t3ma ribbon filled indicator   
  
Change the i factor into 2000 or even 1000.   
  
Goto your navigator folder,   
rightclick on the indicator,   
2nd position: Edit  
  
look for this setting and if it is too big, change this:  
  
for(i=2000; i>=0; i--)   
// iCustom( string symbol, int timeframe, string name, ..., int mode, int shift)

restart MT4

If you are using any of Kino's Close_above_ribbons indicators..... Detach all of them, because all those indicators are in need of a modification with regard to filling up the logfile under MT4/experts dramatically..... ultimately slowing down your computer to standstill when all space one your harddrive has been consumed.  
  
To get rid of this problem:  
  
1\. Detach those indicators from all charts  
  
2\. Close down MT4.  
  
3\. Next open MT4/experts/logs and delete all the logfiles you see there. _(B.T.W. Could be Gigabyte files !!!!)_  
  
4\. Restart MT4 and check the experts Tab on the MT4 Terminal window if you still see any continues repeating messages..... which shouldn't be the case now.  
  
5\. Have patience and wait for Kino's upgraded version.  
  
Cheers, John

TF30Zone is at times the widest of them all.... Therefore it offers possibilities to trade inside its bounderies. Where it says on your chart: "Would anyone take this trade?".... it's obvious you are to late to enter.

You see this funny little **_Flipper Nose Pattern_** over and over again with TFZones........ and where it appears it's most of the time quite good for entries. B.T.W Pipdistance towards your Blue TFZone is about 35 pips. So this is a nice scalp.

LSs,  
  
The longer you work with TFZones the easier it gets.... for you will develop an eye for the entries (plus exits). Actually you can see this short developing for a while.  
  
Where it says: "TF30 seem to resist again" in fact price is bouncing back on heavy resistance of both upper ribbon of TF30Zone (magenta) and lower ribbon of TF15 (blue-ish), i.e. the gray zone in between those ribbons shows a triangle narrowing resistance area. At the crossing halfway this chart.... you have to picture a new triangle of resistance forming between those ribbons,..... you now can only see the blue-ish ribbon. The yellow TF5Zone draws the other line on the bottom...... and there is your MultiTimeFrame Triangle where ultimately price is either going to break out to the upside or to the downside.  
  
So let's sum it up: What you see develop here is a dynamic drawn Triangle influenced by all the necessary TF's to make your decision on.....   
  
The stronger resistance is above price. Therefore you already know one thing for sure... **_Price will come down_**.   
  
What you don't know yet is where exactly will this happen? This information is provided by the Yellow TF5Zone widening up and simultaneously crossing below the Magenta Zone. Next you see to trials to breakout to the downside.... the last one succeeds: First Price falls through the opening up Red TF1Zone **_and immediately now price falls down through the opening up Yellow TF5Zone as well. Exactly there you take your short entry_**..... for all resistance underneath now has been broken.  
  
Cheers, John

Good observation. Here there are two possible entries for Long:  
  
1\. Right at the bottom of the TF30Zone (Magenta) at the second Blue Dot around 10:15 hrs.... exactly above TF1Zone.  
  
Price stops at narrowing TF15Zone (Blue). Next Price retraces nicely back towards the combo support of TF1Zone and TF30Zone traders.... than again price wants to go up again and now breaks through the TF15Zone  
  
2\. The second entry is what I call a Gateway Passage. _(BTW Other examples of Gataway passages are in the pdf-file compiled by Jazz1964)._ Exactly at the red line you have drawn here at 11:17 hrs price passes the crossing of TF15Zone ribbons right in the middle. (= Gateway)  
  
BTW. I am beginning to like your charts more and more. Working with them is easy and quite visual. Thanks for this contribution to the thread.

Anyway, I think this may result in higher volatility once again.... f.i. another increase in daily High-Low range. Because the institutions and other big players will have to take another approach to their portfolio's and now will have to react sooner. Could become a better market for for small traders though.  
  
On the other hand this makes sense why Alapari, IBFX and others all of a sudden are changing their commission policies into 5 digits "robbery". Five digits gives more space I guess to switch to Floating Pips commissions than with 4 digits and Fixed?  
  
Maybe we ultimately all have to switch over to brokers that remain true to their original functioning..... being brokers taking a fair fixed commission, instead of becoming hunters using a wide variety of Pip-hunting commission strategies.  
  
It would be a good thing if the NFA would finally declare rules for this in the interest of individual traders, because without clear regulations this is going to end in some cases in ordinary theft.....  
  
Just my thoughts, John

Hi Pipster,  
Did you try this? It' s in the code.  
  
" LocalTimeZone: TimeZone for which MT4 shows your local time,   
e.g. 1 or 2 for Europe (GMT+1 or GMT+2 (daylight   
savings time). Use zero for no adjustment.  
  
DestTimeZone: TimeZone for the session from which to calculate  
the levels (e.g. 1 or 2 for the European session  
(without or with daylight savings time).   
Use zero for GMT  
  
Example: If your MT server is living in the EST (Eastern Standard Time,   
GMT-5) zone and want to calculate the levels for the London trading  
session (European time in summer GMT+1), then enter -5 for   
LocalTimeZone, 1 for Dest TimeZone.   
  
Please understand that the LocalTimeZone setting depends on the  
time on your MetaTrader charts (for example the demo server   
from MetaQuotes always lives in CDT (+2) or CET (+1), no matter  
what the clock on your wall says.  
  
If in doubt, leave everything to zero. "

Kijun and Tenkan lines are both a kind of moving averages with different settings. We only use one of these lines, The Kijun (29).   
The way we use it is for tradeguidance, we look how price is situated to the line. If price is above the line, we don't like entry shorts at that moment and vice versa.   
You can also use the Kijun for guiding your exit.  
  
Read the posts on page 135, it is described there.  
Or search the pdf file on the word 'KijunTenkan'....  
Got it?

Hey LSs,  
  
Yes I was aware of the TF30 Ribbon, which could give support. But everything was strong pointing down whith power while TF30 was widening (so not too much Support).   
Funny you asked this, because at my entry I thought about your own remark today, saying " .....being too careful sometimes? (: )"  
  
I know there are people scanning all threads about trading systems searching for the holy grail which have to make them rich without investing in time and knowledge. I have never been such a trader (and student). And I know some very good traders have looked to the Ribbon system and didn't take the time to find the big benefits of it.....no prob at all.   
**I found that the ribbons always give you a very good view on what is happening right now.** I have had in the past trading systems on my chart from which I thought "yes this is great" but after a while I always thought: okay, my indicators are giving me a signal right now, but I don't have a good feel where we are and if it is okay to trust the signal...... so I didn't take the trade...and didn't take the next one. But with the ribbons in combination with some good indicators I got a good feel about what is happening, where are the risks and where are the better opportunities.  
The ribbons sometimes don't let me trade a nice move, saying me it isn't a high prob trade. Yes, sometimes I feel sad about that. But looking at my trade results I am very proud that I have so less bad trades!! I am sure it is the result of knowing when the risk of sideways markets is there, .....and of getting whipsawed. So I actually don't mind to miss some good trades.   
At the other hand, it also happens I enter a trade very early after a reversal, because the ribbons tell me it is okay.  
  
When your friend thinks it is complicated, He is most likely looking to a part of the chart where the ribbons are not matching. When he thinks "what is this??" ....well, don't trade at that point, I think it is not a good trading setup! Good opportunities with Ribbos are looking clear! So when it is not clear, it is not good to trade.  
  
In this thread there is enough material gathered to learn the ribbons in a few days. The pdf will help for sure and in post#1 everything is available to setup the chart. Also you know there are people who will give support.   
  
Cheers, Jazz

This chartgraph is currenty clearly in an NTZ. There are two reasons for that:  
  
First of all notice how close the yellow Spudfibo lines are packed together... everyone of those can be a line support or resistance. Longs as well as shorts in such areas bounce to soon on those lines. Preferably pipdistance has to be more than 35 to get into a trade.....  
At the end of this chart on the right you can see how difficult it is for price to get above the Spudfibo.... Price falls back to make a retracement towards yellow TF5Zone >>>>> There would be a chance for a breakout to the upside.... However all these Spudfibo's close together still makes it risky to enter a long here. How did it go from there?  
  
Secondly price and TF1Zone are for the greater part in this chart in between TF15 and TF5 Zone. These Zones here also are too close together to enter trades. The better trade setups arrive when TF1Zone makes a retracement back towards TF5Zone (or sometimes TF15Zone) under or above all other Zones.  
  
Furthermore support and resistance is in the TFZones itself in the first place. How to use triangles to determine breakouts, please check some examples I gave on page 132..... F.i. in one example where you can see that the stronger resistance is provided by the lower TFZones (i.e. TF15 and TF30).  
  
Hope this helps, John

Hi Pipster,  
  
I follow your reasoning, however you made a major mistake. If you look at both setups on this chart...... you know immediately why..... Your retracement didn't happen above or under all Zones..... instead it happened inside quite a narrow TF30 Zone.  
  
It should be like it's the case at the end of this chart. Nevertheless there is much hesitation here as well because of all the Spudfibo's overhead. Please check the chart below.  
  
A retracement is only to be considered powerful and valid....... **_in open space....._** whenever that retracement of TF1Zone occurs towards TF5Zone (and in some cases towards TF15Zone).   
  
When between TFZones the same has to be true..... **_there also has to be enough open space when between TFZones....._** for price to be able to jump out of TF1Zone (longs) or to fall out of TF1Zone (shorts).  
  
Open space = when Pipdistance towards another TFZone or Fib- or Pivotline is more than 35 Pips.  
  
So watch it and good luck next time, John

Hi John,  
  
This indi is based on Zigzag indicator and there is no reference point for it such as daily open or daily high or fixed hours...   
I mean it just draws fibo levels between 2 points of zigzag peaks , it will change everytime zigzag peak changes (the highest and lowest peaks in a special range which could be defined). I think if you change the color (in the color tab from 255,255,255 to another one) you'll understand what I mean...  
  
As you know the zigzag is an amazing indicator which pointing to the short trends and price retracements, but you should know how to set the settings for every timeframes to eliminate the noise. You can also change the ExtDepth value (for the mentioned special range) to find out what settings work best for your time frame.  
  
Reza

hi ; new version 2 (before 3 , 4 etc ...) so How that works =  
with a simple glance if you see that  ALL the nb of pips to close are red = then close is _below all ribbons , green above cool no ? _  
  
_**nb pips to close**_ is red = close is below this ribbon , green above  
**_CCIs_ **are red or green (below or above a level you can change = zero , 100; -67 or +67 or 228 lol) and _you can change also periods of CCIs_  
_**RSI** 8 is _red below or above a level that you can change =45, 55 or 50 or 80) and _you also can change also period of RSI_  
_**Price**_ is Green if up and Red if down  
_**ADX**_ is Green if > 20 or else and Red if <0  
_**SMA** 50_ or else is red if above bar close , Green below  
_**Time to next bar**_ nothing to precise  
_**local time**_ nothing to precise !  
  
if you want something else let me know !  
  
kino

Hi Satini,  
I hope you don't mind if I take a minute to answer your question, I saw your post was 25 hours old. John can complement if he can give further insights.  
  
The second entry was a very good High Probability Trade setup. Price bounced up from closing TF5 zone together with TF1 which indicates strong support. No TF zones ahead which you can easely see on both Kino indicators. CCI has strong momentum, and both FX primes pointing to uptrend.   
  
Your entry on the first arrow was not a high prob trade. Congrats with the pips, I think you made a nice ride. However, it wasn't a safe entry. Close above you, in the direction of your trade, you have got resistance from TF5 zone, which didn't gave support short before. TF 5 zone was just trying to turn to a closing triangle. At your entry point it was not clear that TF1 zone was giving this support and was able to win over TF5 resistance.   
CCI had negative momentum! The longer FXPrime indicator was neutral and didn't paint the white alert dots.   
  
Waiting for TF1 zone retracing to TF5 was a possibility. It doens't happen all the time. CCI indicated good health (no divergence) so it was good to enter here.   
  
Have a nice trading day. I am just taking some holiday this week.   
Cheers, Jazz

Welcome Mike!  
The best thing you can do is learning the stuff from the pdf and get familiair with the template from post#1.  
In this thread you can also find the newest developments like the indicator on which you're questioning about. It's a really good one, I like it.   
In this indicator there are several components which don't really belong to this Ribbon system.   
When something new is tested and can fit into the system, it will be in the next update in post#1. So you can wait to learn all indicators which are (and will be) posted.   
  
But if you wat to know the MonitorV2: Take a look at my picture.  
The ADX ad RSI values aren't part of our system. SMA50 isn't also.   
CCI21 isn't used in the latest templates anymore. This CCi21 is integrated in the upper FXPrime indicator. But to show you what it is, I placed a doubleCCi in my chart below. You can forget about it. Or remember: if it's green and positive, the entryCCi is above zero (and vice versa).   
  
If the distances from the ribbons are all red, that means price is below all ribbons (look for short high probability trades).   
If the distances from the ribbons are all green, that means price is below all ribbons (look for long high probability trades).   
Maybe you want to trade between the ribbons (that's where distances are red AND green). You can now easely look if pipdistance is >35 pips, which is a requirement.   
  
Hope this helps you.   
Cheers, Jazz

I want to thank everyone for their contributions to this thread. The indicators are very strong and it's up to each of us to be able to interpret them according to our goals and to exit according to the plan. Now, that's the problem I've been having. I only trade "live" and at full lots, so this is real money! My trading success is at 80% which to me is acceptable. Normally my entries are "right on" and I'm not retracing more than a few pips. But there are times when the exit is not real good. I wait a bit for it to turn and then the loss ends up bigger than I need. I know there have been responses written regarding a 20 pip stop loss, but sometimes that's huge and could have been cut much sooner. I know, if my entries are normally very good, I probably should exit pretty quickly when I see it not working, but sometimes that price does come around and do what you believed it would.   
  
My guess is some of you have encountered the same thing. If not, you are trading wizards and I compliment you! If you have experienced this, what is the indicator/criteria you use to exit and just admit it wasn't the best executed trade? Any thoughts you folks have would be greatly appreciated.   
  
I look forward to the continuation of this thread, because it has helped clear up some other inconsistencies in my trading plan. Thanks again.  
  
Steve

First of all: my excuses for my previous post!  
I hoped I could find time this week for trading and posting on this thread, but it's different.   
  
Okay, I want to show you 2 pics.   
Reason is the orchid coloured TF30 Zone. I think it is good to repeat what John told about that Zone at the time he introduced it. He said:  
  
_"You will notice that TF30Zone is of less importance for entry decision and actually is more or less only usefull to identify support and resistance at greater distances. As such the edges of TF30Zone (=TF30Ribbon) most of the time work more the same as Pivot-and Fiblines."_  
  
That's my opinion on the TF30 Zone too. Actually I have to say that if you don't pay attention to that principle, you will mis the boat and (even worse) will entry too late /getting in bad trades.   
However the TF30 Zone is on my charts for reason the 'pivot' function.   
  
NB: Because of the original intention of the TF30 Zone, the #Kino_close_above_ribbons indicator doesn't have TF30 Zone in it's calculation.  
  
pay attention to the big distance between Yesterdays High which is reached on the chart and yellow TF5 zone. In my opinion it happens often that price retraces to this Zone. In this case it was much further.  
  
For those who think: Jazz' chart is different from mine......yes, I had data probems....I am missing half an hour data.

It's a game between the next factors. Talking about an upmove:  
\- is CCI strong? Negative Divergence into CCI has to make you careful.   
\- is the support from TF zones strong? e.g. if TF5 zone is far below, it's risky because these traders can take profit near an important pivot or fibo level. But if two or more TF edges are very nearby, then they can give strong support.  
\- did price already made a strong upmove? If yes, be carefull.  
  
See my attachment. Price breaks out all Zones and comes near to Yesterdays High Pivot. Then it falls back to exactly TF1 Zone and goes up again. Take a sharp look at CCI, which doesn't come high again, showing negative divergence. This is a warning that the pivot can be too strong. Pipdistance to Y-High is very small and Y-High is an important pivot. So if you made your entry on the first vertical line, you better be extra carefull.   
  
Price falls down, making lower lows an a lower high. New down move? I don't think so! Much support overhere from TF5 and TF15 and TF30.  
  
Now I am going to wait for CCI breaking the yellow resistance trendline. If that occurs I can try a long. It happened...I made my entry long, and.....my internet connection and telephone broke down....WOW....okay, call my broker by cell phone and closed my position with a little profit above the pivot!  
  
Your question about pipdistance.... I think 15 pips at minimum. John, what's your opinion? I am not trading Forex, I think most people know that overhere. I am trading FESX index. This system also works on Indexes, futures etcetera.   
The trade I made here was too close to the pivotline, but I wanted to beat it. Usually I take around a wave length as minimum. _But that's no rule._

Hi all,  
  
just want to say I am still dedicated to the FX50 system with Ribbons.  
Unfortunately I don't have time to trade so I dont share charts with you these times.   
  
In the future I want to come back here. I want to do a visual backtest on the high prob trade setups, looking for the % winners and losers on EURUSD. I think it will be almost the same as a previous backtest I made and publiced overhere. The result was about 80% winners if I remember correctly.   
  
Kino, sorry, really don't have time for a small pdf. The best trade setups are if price is under/above all ribbons AND after price made a nice pullback. Price shouldn't have been on the way for a long time already, because then you can expect a retracement. Look for CCI (strength/trendlines/divergences). Be carefull with entry nearby pivots and fibo levels.   
Me myself like to trade between the Ribbons too when the next S&R from the ribbons is at enough pipdistance.   
  
I find it very responible to look at price action as a result of the behaviour of the different groups of traders, each with their own time horizon. since february they are always on my charts as the basis of my trading.   
  
Hope everybody is okay!

Hey all how's trading going. I have been away but back now nice to see this thread moving along. Any way I have a great idea for a trailing stop ea.  
  
I will try to explain this the best I can.  
I need an ea that will first close all orders at profit  
second a trailing stop added  
third a close orders at loss in pips  
fourth read below I tried to explain the best I can. NOTE: this needs to all be in pips not dollars like 0.5 etc.  
**Here seems to be the tricky part when the ea hits the trailing stop at whatever i input lets say 20 pips, now I want the option lets say the market goes the other direction against me. I want to be able to have the ea close a percentage of the order say at 10 pips. This way if it does go to 0 I at least get something out of the market.****This would be great for scalping for all of us**. Kinon or somebody can you look at this. I have enclosed a trailing ea maybe you can just add to it.  
Thanks let me know what you think.  
fxtrading24  
  
**So the inputs would be**  
**All possessions** True or False  
**Profit Trailing** True or False  
**Trailing stop**   
**Profit Target**  
**Trailing Step**  
**Hard Stop**  
**Then Close Partial oreder(** This is when the trailing stop has been hit here you would add the amount of order to close if the trailing stop heads back to 0)  
**Close order amount** This is when the trailing stop has been hit here you would add how many pips before it closes the partial order.  
  
**What I am getting at is lets say you go long eur/usd and you set your trailing stop at 10 ok so you hit the trailing stop and then the market reverses and lets say you want the ea to close half the order at 5 pips you still gain if it goes to 0.**

I have been using the JE Ribbon system and have found it very good. I would like to share what I have found to be the real power in the system. I found using the TF1 ribbon allows you to be caught up too much in the whipsaw effect. I have found the real power to be in the TF5 ribbon. To be more precise - when the Tick Ribbon moves above and below the TF5 Ribbon. (I have found it easier to just have a 13 ema instead of the Tick Ribbon). Trading these ribbons provides very good risk/reward ratios most of the time and lets you cut your losses short and your profits run. I also use the double cci with sma with settings of 480 for the trend cci and 200 for the sma - this provides a very good filter for removing the crosses that dont go anywhere. S&R levels are important for exits along with Fib Extentions. It is the best system I have used and has produced consistent good profits. Below is an example of how it even works in a relatively flat market.  
  
[http://i5.photobucket.com/albums/y16...vot_210709.jpg](http://i5.photobucket.com/albums/y165/m10man/eur_usd_tf5_pivot_210709.jpg)

For longs - when the 13 ema has moved through the top of the TF5 ribbon and the cci is green or has just crossed above the zero line.  
  
For shorts - when the 13 ema has moved through the bottom of the TF5 ribbon and the cci is orange or has just crossed below the zero line.  
  
The sma also gives a clue as to direction and the other higher TF ribbons along with fib and Murrey Math S&R levels give further evidence of how good the trade is and when to exit.  
  
I am not interested in trading the short term chop, I want high probable trades and the 480 cci gives me that and works well with the 13ema/TF5 crosses.

The easiest exit is when the 13ema crosses back into the TF5 Ribbon. However that is mostly a late exit and you will have given up profits. I use Elliott wave with Fib retracements and extentions. I look for clusters, ie,. on extentions after retracements I look for support or resistance levels and a murrey math level that fall on the extentions of 127%, 138%, 161% or even 261%. If there is a clear cluster then I will set my limit there. On retracement (counter trend) trades (which have to have a clear risk/reward of more than 2 to 1) I look for a cluster around the fib levels 38.2%, 50% or 61.8%.  
  
I believe in the rule of not letting a winner turn into a loser. So I pull my stop up to break even when about 20 pips up and move it up under obvious pull backs. It is a juggling act of protecting your profits and still giving the trade room. Another method would be to keep moving your stop to just the other side of the TF5 ribbon.  
  
You could also use the Smoothed Heikenashi candles as per FX-prime for your exits, but I also find them to give a late exit.  
  
I am happy to hear any better suggestions.  
  
I trade this system live on the Eur/Usd. 

...20% method, 80% mindset...

After some more intensive testing I believe I have improved the system even further. I have found it to be so, but you will have to test it and make your own judgement. In case anyone would like to test/use it I have attached it.  
  
The cci is gone as the moving averages in the ribbons tell the same thing, so why have a double up of information. I have used sma's for the ribbons as I could get them to reflect price movement more accurately.  
  
Fxprime is there just for extra confirmation.  
  
The 2MA Crossover arrows are not an entry signal. They are just an early warning that an entry may be about to happen. This is so you dont have to sit there and watch the computer all the time.  
  
Entry: When the 13ema crosses through the TF5 ribbon and fxprime says go and you have no obstruction from the higher TF ribbons.  
  
Exit: When the 13ema crosses back right through the TF5 ribbon or when a fibretracement/fibextention is hit.  
  
  
Stop loss: 5 pips or so under or above the TF5 ribbon (depending on long or short entry). If your risk level allows it, to give extra room place it under/above the previous swing high/low.  
  
Happy Pipping! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Hello Wakayama I'm in the same situation than you but maybe this can help.   
1) I saw that in some cases before the "second high probability trade" appear a white dot in the fxprime v2 alerting the proximation of the trade (like you can see in your example).  
2) Look at kijuntenkan to be aligned with 1M kino or going down 1M kino   
(I think this is important)   
3) Wait for the 5M kino to be wide and take trend.  
4) wait for retracement of TrandCCi  
  
If you take this as rule, you dont enter in trade 1 because rule 1,2,3 and 4  
In trade 2 I spect price going down for elliot wave, not going up, anyway you can see trendCCi down and 5Mkino taking trend down.  
In trade 3 you can see all 4 "rules" completed, an elliot wave move, TrendCCi strongth enought and CCi SMA crossing 0.  
I hope this can help you.  
Luis

No problem.  
  
I have them grouped as they relate to one another.  
EURUSD, USDJPY, EURJPY. (The eurjpy movement is the eurusd x usdjpy.)  
GBPUSD, GPBJPY, EURGBP. (The gbpjpy movement is the gbpusd x usdjpy)  
AUDUSD, AUDJPY, EURAUD. (The audjpy movement is the aususd x usdjpy)  
USDCAD  
USDCHF  
NZDUSD  
  
If you do some research on Correlation you will get an idea of which move in relation to one another. For example the EURUSD and USDCHF mostly mirror each other, and the Commodity Currencies, AUDUSD, USDCAD, NZDUSD all tend to move similarly.   
  
By watching so many pairs it gives you a better idea of movements and you can pick the best signal out of them for the best risk/reward.  
  
cheers.

Being in Australia I trade the Asian and half the London sessions. There are at least 3 good signals a day in these sessions. I quite often wake up to see really good signals and movement in the New York session particularly on the EURUSD. I only take one signal/trade at a time, but the reason I watch so many pairs is that it gives you a choice between the correlated pairs to pick the signal with the best position (risk/reward).  
  
The system so far this month has shown a 72% success rate, and netted a 14% increase in my account. This could have been a more if I had of let more trades run. I am now seeing that using an M1 chart and a H1 chart together on the same pair improves targets and trade lengths.  
  
If there is enough interest I may think about starting a new trading thread for this system where we can focus on it and use it to greater success. 

...20% method, 80% mindset...

Hi,  
  
I am not really interested in other teading systems. Each trading system is really like having a business. Best to focus on one. Each has it ups and downs.   
  
Best to stick to one and really get to know it then to jump around from method to method.  
  
Good trading system:  
  
1) + expectancy  
2) Low risk  
3) Wins over the long term  
4) Completely automatic and automated. This is a huge factor for me. I'd rather make 20% on auto pilto then 30% bu have to watch the markets all day.   
  
The biggest problem most new traders face is they are bombarded with get rich quick....Lower your expectancy and decide if trading is for you or not. This isn't a hobby.

Hi There,  
  

In order to import more 1 minute bars you can do the following:  
\- press and hold 'Home' key (fn+left arrow on Mac) on desired 1 min chart until the chart stops  
scrolling. It will download more bars from the server. The fastest way doing it is to zoom out  
maximally the 1 min chart first and then press the 'Home' key.  
\- alternatively you can go to the history center (press F2), select desired symbol's 1 min

history and press the 'Downlad' button.  
  
Hope this helps  
  
P07

I just wanted to attach a chart to show the power of what Kino has done with the ICHI. This is a Bare 15 minute chart with no indicators. The Senkou Span B is the flatter thicker part of the Kumo Cloud. Just like with the RIBBONS you can see how resistance and support can work off of each time period Kumo and Senkou Span B. I also attached an excellent pdf on the ICHI by some pros who trade this style. I will also attach my template which emphasizes those areas that are important to understand by there thickness. You will see on the chart I posted how price once clear the 15 Minute Senkou Span B than finds resistance at the 30 minute and 60 minute Senkou Span B before breaking free for a short long. You can also see nicely how the Senkou Span B than switches to become the flat base of each Kumo cloud on all the time frames. If you look to the dark brown area of the right bottom corner of the template you can see that on the 4 hour kumo the SenKou Span B would already have to be support because all you can see is Senkou Span A. This is another really GREAT contribution Kino has made to this thread taking what he has learned and applying it to the ICHI. It also is in line of John's very visual way of trading the RIBBONS. It also works just fine with the FX indicator system settings for the CCI. The power of the ICHI is it can be a whole system without indicators at the bottom of the chart. The ICHI was designed so you could trade with out indicators. I have always liked the ICHI but this MTF view of it is extremely powerful and what I have been looking for to trade it.

It than rises through the gray 30 minute time zone spans A and B but takes its time. It hesitates at the red Senkou Span A (dashes) of the 240 minute. It crosses after some hour hesitation at the 60 minute green thick Senkou Span A. It than jumps to the red thick Senkou Span A of the 240 minute time zone. After several hours it breaks through until price finally exhaust itself. It than is falling back to the base 15 minute time zone of the chart where it starting to catch support from the aqua A Senkou Span.   
  
At the same time you will see on the chart each time zone Ichimoku do the a Senkou Span Twist with resistance becoming support. Looking at a chart with the Kino Ichimoku tool is fascinating. Seeing support like this can help you stick with a trade longer than you might if you were looking a chart with out the Kino Ichimoku tool. .

This is not a trade but here is a ranging EURCHF chart right before FOMC today. I was wondering what the influence of the 1440 time period or Daily Senkou Spans would be on a chart as small as the 15 minute chart period. The purple line is the Senkou Span A of the 1440 as it runs through the 15 minute and 30 minute clouds. I just put the spans of these large time periods because their clouds are often so big you are trading inside them or outside them. I do the same thing with the 240 minute. Multiple times price comes down and touches the purple span and at the end is consolidating around the span. Every higher time period span can impact the 15 minute chart. So to some up. The chart is based on the 15 minute period with the Ichimoku of this period the primary trading system. The higher time period Ichimoku clouds and their spans can be seen on the chart except for the 240 minute or 4 hour and 1440 minute or Daily. With these I just place the spans not to clutter the chart. They are there to see resistance and support. It would seem that the Kino MTF ICHIMOKU displays dynamically support and resistance. The trend CCI is there with the -67 to 67 area blacked out as a filter. I also use a multi-time period RSI as a filter on my chart. All ideas from this thread. There is an ATR superimposed over the CCI as a volatility or enthusiasm indicator often getting an increase in ATR prior to a big move. I use tick volume on my charts and find it useful.
